natural problem: Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$.
natural solution: \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}

x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2}&= x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+3+2\sqrt{2}-3\\ &=(x-(1+\sqrt{2}))^2-(\sqrt{3})^2\\ &=(x-1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}). \end{align}Likewise, \begin{align} x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}=(x-1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}), \end{align}so the roots of the quartic are $1\pm\sqrt{2}\pm\sqrt{3}$.

Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "roots P = {a,b,c,d}"
and h2 : "sum abs {a,b,c,d} = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
shows  "2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3 = sum abs (roots P)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}
 x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2}&= x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+3+2\sqrt{2}-3\\ &=(x-(1+\sqrt{2}))^2-(\sqrt{3})^2\\ &=(x-1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}). \end{align}Likewise, \begin{align} x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}=(x-1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}), \end{align}so the roots of the quartic are $1\pm\sqrt{2}\pm\sqrt{3}$.
 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "roots P = {a,b,c,d}"
and h2 : "sum abs {a,b,c,d} = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
shows  "2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3 = sum abs (roots P)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a polynomial $P(x) = x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8$ with roots $a, b, c,$ and $d$, if the sum of the absolute values of the roots equals $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$, prove that $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$ equals the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $P(x)$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "\<exists> a b c d. P a = 0 \<and> P b = 0 \<and> P c = 0 \<and> P d = 0"
shows  "abs a + abs b + abs c + abs d = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}
 x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2}&= x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+3+2\sqrt{2}-3\\ &=(x-(1+\sqrt{2}))^2-(\sqrt{3})^2\\ &=(x-1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}). \end{align}Likewise, \begin{align} x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}=(x-1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}), \end{align}so the roots of the quartic are $1\pm\sqrt{2}\pm\sqrt{3}$.
 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "\<exists> a b c d. P a = 0 \<and> P b = 0 \<and> P c = 0 \<and> P d = 0"
shows  "abs a + abs b + abs c + abs d = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the absolute values of the roots of the equation $x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8 = 0$. Sum them up. The final answer is $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "poly [1, -4, -4, 16, -8] x = 0"
shows  "abs (x1) + abs (x2) + abs (x3) + abs (x4) = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
where "x1 = root1" and "x2 = root2" and "x3 = root3" and "x4 = root4"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}
 x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2}&= x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+3+2\sqrt{2}-3\\ &=(x-(1+\sqrt{2}))^2-(\sqrt{3})^2\\ &=(x-1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}). \end{align}Likewise, \begin{align} x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}=(x-1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}), \end{align}so the roots of the quartic are $1\pm\sqrt{2}\pm\sqrt{3}$.
 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "poly [1, -4, -4, 16, -8] x = 0"
shows  "abs (x1) + abs (x2) + abs (x3) + abs (x4) = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
where "x1 = root1" and "x2 = root2" and "x3 = root3" and "x4 = root4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the roots of the polynomial $x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8 = 0$. If $x1$, $x2$, $x3$, and $x4$ are the roots of this polynomial, show that the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8 = 0"
shows  "\<Sum> r\<leftarrow>roots. abs r = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
where "roots = poly_roots (x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}
 x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2}&= x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+3+2\sqrt{2}-3\\ &=(x-(1+\sqrt{2}))^2-(\sqrt{3})^2\\ &=(x-1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}). \end{align}Likewise, \begin{align} x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}=(x-1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}), \end{align}so the roots of the quartic are $1\pm\sqrt{2}\pm\sqrt{3}$.
 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8 = 0"
shows  "\<Sum> r\<leftarrow>roots. abs r = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
where "roots = poly_roots (x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the roots of the equation $x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8 = 0$. The sum of the absolute values of these roots should be $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "poly [1, -4, -4, 16, -8] x = 0"
shows  "sum_list (map abs (roots4 1 (-4) (-4) 16 (-8))) = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}
 x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2}&= x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+3+2\sqrt{2}-3\\ &=(x-(1+\sqrt{2}))^2-(\sqrt{3})^2\\ &=(x-1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}). \end{align}Likewise, \begin{align} x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}=(x-1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}), \end{align}so the roots of the quartic are $1\pm\sqrt{2}\pm\sqrt{3}$.
 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "poly [1, -4, -4, 16, -8] x = 0"
shows  "sum_list (map abs (roots4 1 (-4) (-4) 16 (-8))) = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that $x$ is a solution to the polynomial equation $x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8 = 0$, find the sum of the absolute values of all the roots of this equation. The final answer is $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. is_root f x"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. abs x) (roots f) = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}
 x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2}&= x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+3+2\sqrt{2}-3\\ &=(x-(1+\sqrt{2}))^2-(\sqrt{3})^2\\ &=(x-1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}). \end{align}Likewise, \begin{align} x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}=(x-1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}), \end{align}so the roots of the quartic are $1\pm\sqrt{2}\pm\sqrt{3}$.
 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. is_root f x"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. abs x) (roots f) = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a function $f(x) = x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8$, find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $f(x)$. The final answer is $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x = 0"
shows  "\<Sum>x. abs x = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}

 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x = 0"
shows  "\<Sum>x. abs x = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the sum of the absolute values of all real roots of the equation $x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8 = 0$. The final answer is $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8 = 0"
shows  "abs (root 4 x) + abs (root 3 (4 * x)) + abs (root 2 (4 * x)) + abs x = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}

 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8 = 0"
shows  "abs (root 4 x) + abs (root 3 (4 * x)) + abs (root 2 (4 * x)) + abs x = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the sum of the absolute values of the fourth root of $x$, the cube root of $4x$, the square root of $4x$, and $x$ if $x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8 = 0$. The final answer is $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.

theorem
fixes x :: real

(* ### Problem

 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8 = 0"
shows  "sum_list (map abs (roots (x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8))) = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"

a_8.informal problem: Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of the equation $x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8 = 0$. The final answer is $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "poly_roots P = {r1, r2, r3, r4}"
shows  "abs r1 + abs r2 + abs r3 + abs r4 = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the absolute values of the roots of $x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8=0$. The final Answer is 2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} x^4-4x^3-4x^2+16x-8&=(x^4-4x^3+4x^2)-(8x^2-16x+8)\\ &=x^2(x-2)^2-8(x-1)^2\\ &=(x^2-2x)^2-(2\sqrt{2}x-2\sqrt{2})^2\\ &=(x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2})(x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}). \end{align}But noting that $(1+\sqrt{2})^2=3+2\sqrt{2}$ and completing the square, \begin{align}
 x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+2\sqrt{2}&= x^2-(2+2\sqrt{2})x+3+2\sqrt{2}-3\\ &=(x-(1+\sqrt{2}))^2-(\sqrt{3})^2\\ &=(x-1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}). \end{align}Likewise, \begin{align} x^2-(2-2\sqrt{2})x-2\sqrt{2}=(x-1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(x-1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}), \end{align}so the roots of the quartic are $1\pm\sqrt{2}\pm\sqrt{3}$.
 Only one of these is negative, namely $1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3}$, so the sum of the absolute values of the roots is $$(1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})+(1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})+(1-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})-(1-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{3})=\boxed{2+2\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 4 * x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 8"
and h1 : "poly_roots P = {r1, r2, r3, r4}"
shows  "abs r1 + abs r2 + abs r3 + abs r4 = 2 + 2 * sqrt 2 + 2 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a polynomial $P(x) = x^4 - 4x^3 - 4x^2 + 16x - 8$, find the sum of the absolute values of its roots. The final answer is $2 + 2\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$.
